description: Ate here before going to a concert at the Regency Ballroom. The food felt nutritious, healthy, fresh, and their portions were generous. (See the calamari appetizer) the salmon melted in your mouth. Don't skip dessert the olive oil cake was the best part of the entire meal. All-in-all it was the perfect start to a San Francisco evening out....
author: Kristin A.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here around 6:30 on a Friday and were trying to catch a movie at 7:30. There was no line but only bar seating was available as all the tables were reserved. Our waitress quickly took our drink and food orders and it was great. Wine and appetizer came within 10 minutes but then the waiting began. 

We sat there for about 30 minutes drinking our wine and chatting with the waitress returning intermittently telling us it'll just be a few more minutes. By now it was 7:10- still ok. Another 10 minutes and the waitress again tells us it's another few minutes. We've been waiting for 40 min for our food by now and had to leave for the movie so we asked for it to be wrapped up. It probably took them another 5-10 minutes to actually box everything up (which by the way was dripping with oil soon after). 

After carrying the $60 boxed food to the movie theater and back home, we did actually taste the food and it was fortunately quite delicious. However, the overall experience has left a bad impression and we won't be back anytime soon.
author: Joanna H.

description:
I stumbled upon this place and was intrigued as Gardenias is my favorite flower...
Welcomed by the owner who didn't trust I could spend the cash and truly not friendly.. tried to strike up a conversation and she was just too busy...and there were 4 tables seated.

Sat at the bar with a friend and waitress was attentive but felt a bit rushed... again tried making conversation about what to order...she really couldn't help me decide...
I must say the atmosphere is wonderful and the food quite good. Fig salad was good.. a tad too much honey.. short ribs were falling off the bone but a little too much star anise...a bit of a foodie I am...
I would recommend this place and I will be back.. but...and the olive cake was pretty
Darn tasty!!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Gardenias has become the restaurant I always hoped it would be -- in my neighborhood, you can hear yourself talk, with spectacular food.  It took a while -- my first three visits were okay, but not at the level I expected given the Woodward Gardens history.  Now Gardenias can hold its own against any restaurant in the city.  My short ribs with star anise were spectacular, and we both loved the appetizers we shared (figs and squid, separately).  Bravo!  Will be my go-to place starting now.
author: Robin W.

description:
Cute new Americana restaurant in San Francisco with good amounts of vegetarian and seafood options on their menu.

I went with a group of 6 people around 7:30pm on a Saturday night. The vibe was very cozy with lots of pretty white string lights decorating the restaurant.

The service was friendly and attentive.

I love brussel sprouts but their brussel sprouts appetizer was a little underwhelming - it was intentionally a  cold, more of a salad-style dish. I prefer warm, crispy, crunchy brussel sprouts.

My duck leg entree was absolutely mouthwatering! The duck had a great glaze with just the perfect amount of salty and sweet flavors. And the cheesy potato au gratin served on the side was delectable. I only wish I had more than one duck leg to eat!

Minus one star for my boyfriend's steak entree which was riddled with strings of fat. Hoping it was just a bad cut, but you may want to avoid the steak and chose a different entree.

Overall very pleasant dining experience.
author: Annette K.

description:
When you walk into Gardenias, it has all the appearances of a really fine restaurant: warm, delicate lighting; dark grey oak trim, and an open kitchen with just the right balance of metal and glass.

But that's about it. 

The food was not nearly where the decor was.  Everything we had was meh.  The brussel sprouts salad was meh, just a collection of parts, no greater sum. The braised short ribs were dry and flavorless, and even a sprinkle of salt and pepper could not remedy it.  We even tried to rescue it with desert, a chocolate budino, and it fell flat.  How can you screw up a budino? Sigh.

Really disappointing. Move along, nothing to see here...
author: Saminda W.

description:
This restaurant is a mix of all the good things a customer looking for! We were 9 people over there with 5 kids,the waiter took the order in no time! Brought the dishes for the kids and took the other orders for the rest of the table,was very nice and friendly and definitely made our experience better
The food and wine is really above expectations 
I will surely recommended this place to everyone going to this
author: Moti K.

description:
Tasty food, cute tableware, nice lighting, clean decor.  Easy reservations.  Great for date night, girls night, or family dinner.

I was a little skeptical with some of the negative reviews, but those reviewers also didn't have a lot of reviews or friends... I'm glad I gave this place a shot, because this place is a hidden gem.

Sautéed calamari ($14) - sautéed with red bell peppers, fava beans, and lemon slivers, and served with a dollop of creme fraiche.  Tender, flavorful, nice colors.  Get this.

Hand-cut garlic-scape pesto papardelle ($14) - perfectly cooked pasta, topped with almond slivers for texture, parmesan and chives.  Pesto is creamy, herby (but not overly herby), and appropriately portioned for the pasta.  Yum.

Sautéed steelhead trout ($29) - in a balsamic, brown butter, mustard, and caper sauce.  Served atop wax and French green beans and fingerling potatoes.  The menu doesn't mention mustard, so if you're like me and dislike mustard, be wary--the good thing was that it was just a hint and not present in every bite.  Fish was very well cooked with a bit of pink in the center and crispy skin.  Potatoes were overly cooked with some pieces hard crunchy.  A bit too much brown butter, such that every piece of veggies and potatoes were fully dipped in it.  All in all tasty though, and would get again.

I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and flavor of the food.  They also have cute tea party-esque plates and silverware which is an added plus.  Overall a good find.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Hosted my husband's surprise birthday dinner here and everyone LOVED it! Margie was so helpful coordinating everything and helping me pick out the perfect menu items. The space is intimate and inviting. The staff was so friendly, accommodating and helpful. Their menu is super seasonal and fresh so they update it often. Our favorite dishes that night were the fig, prosciutto, burrata starter and the short ribs. We had such a lovely night and I'm sure we'll all be back again soon!
author: Tori M.

description: Gardenias is such a cute restaurant. a couple friends and I went for dinner before a show at the Fillmore (quick walk away). The service is really good here, and they take reservations! The dishes were all very fresh and tasty, but definitely small portions. Not cheap, but I think it is worth the freshness and ambiance!
author: Kim C.

description:
We live in PAC Heights and walked here for our first time. My wife had ricotta raviolis that were delicious! I had their short ribs and loved them as well. We shard a corn and bean chowder along with a beat and kumquat salad to start. Though our first time here, we give them a solid here stars!
We'll be walking back again.....
author: Kirk M.

description: I had bruscetta, asparigus, and swordfish.  They were all pretty good.  I like my wine also.   Service was a bit off, they forgot our first course and the food took a really long time.
author: Michael E.

description:
Came here with some out-of-town friends. We had decided to switch from a different restaurant last minute. This place had openings on Open Table and solid reviews so we booked it.

Upon approaching the restaurant, you'll notice the outside is adorable. The inside is just as cute and garden inspired.

The three of us ordered:
-Marinated olives
-Plums, roasted beets, oil cured olives, olive oil salad
-Kuri squash, pomegranate, feta, chicories, pepitas, pomegranate vingarette salad
-Seared scallops, Jerusalem artichoke purée, salsa verde with finger lime 
-Pappa del pomodero: heirloom tomato and pepper, eggplant and bread soup, saffron cream
-Sautéed steelhead, shaved fennel, heirloom apples, roasted fingerling potatoes, balsamic caper brown butter

Everything was delicious! The salads were seasonal and fresh. The kuri squash was very hearty. The scallop dish was larger than expected and I really liked the addition of the Jerusalum artichoke puree. The soup surprised me. It's thick and hearty but I didn't taste much in the way of saffron so it doesn't seem to be the best use of an expensive ingredient. My friend found the steelhead a little overcooked. It was less interesting than some of the other dishes but still tasty. 

Prices are not too crazy by SF standards. Gardenias is adorable with spot-on fresh vegetable flavor...which you gotta expect from a place called Gardenias. I'll definitely be back!
author: Ninette C.

description: My sister in law took me here for dinner.  The restaurant feel like if you are having dinner in a garden. We ordered a fig honey plate, gnocchi, salmon, duck leg, coffee, wine, and dessert.  Every single plates was good. Great customer services. We parked at Japantown Public Parking for $2.50 per hour. The walk from the parking garage to the restaurant is about 7 minutes walk.
author: Kim N.

description: We should have stopped after the appetizers. The ricotta cheese raviolis with burnt butter and pappardelle, both house made pastas, were well executed.  The duck was good but the potato and corn with greens on the side were more of a hit for me than they were for my son. My wife's short rib was uninspired. My review might have inched to a 4 star if the service wasn't slow and spotty and if they  didn't charge $4 for bread and butter that was unheated.
author: Ken R.

description:
I hosted my bday dinner at Gardenias this past weekend and all my friends loved it. I had previously been to celebrate another birthday. What do I love about this place? 

1. Super intimate and cozy ambience. This place has charm and personality. There's a chic rustic feel and the owner has put attention to the details and decor. 

2. Superb food and unique menu.  The menu changes and offers eclectic and tasty dishes such as gold & chioga beeta with farro and kumquat.   I split the swordfish and short ribs with my friend and we both loved what we ordered.  For dessert, we ordered a few different ones and shared. Just divine:  pear hazelnut crisp, panna cotta, and meringue, meyer lemon ice cream. 

3. Wonderful service and great staff.  Margie, the owner, was really responsive and pleasant to deal with. She and her staff helped make my bday a wonderful experience.

Thank you, Gardenias!
author: S C.

description: We had an incredible dinner here for our anniversary last night! My mom had surprised us and bought us a beautiful bottle of champagne, and it was ready and waiting on ice. Our server was impeccable, attentive but not too imposing. Every dish we ordered was so fresh and delicious tasting. We started with the bruschetta of ricotta and fresh peas, and the braised artichoke. Then we both got the NY steak for our entree. It had a delicious chimichurri type salsa on top, and the sides were to die for. For dessert we had the brown butter strawberry tarte and the peach raspberry crumble. It was all so so so good. We will definitely be back for another special occasion!
author: Roxanne S.

description: Great choice near The Fillmore, especially if you're not in the mood for sushi/Japanese. Quiet intimate setting, delicious food, friendly staff. However, service was a tad disjointed - maybe it's cause they just opened?
author: Scott L.

description:
Excellent food and served quickly and beautifully.
Very good service and very much kid friendly.
Not cheap but worth the price.
author: Nina O.

description:
The restaurant itself is a really lovely space. It can get a little loud, but its very charming inside.

The service was excellent. Our waitress was clearly running her butt off so I asked if she was unusually busy and she said one of their servers had called in sick so it was just her in the back portion of the restaurant. The food took a little while to come out, but she continually apologized and was incredibly pleasant and sweet. 

The food was as good as the service. The scallops appetizer was delicious. I had the ricotta ravioli for my entree and my boyfriend had the short ribs. Both were amazing. I rarely clean my plate when out for dinner, but there wasn't a morsel leftover. I also think the prices are fair given the quality of the food and the portions.

To top it off, our waitress delivered our check with a to-go box with their berry pie in it as an apology for the wait times. It was unexpected but very appreciated, as the pie was delicious and we definitely didn't mind the wait at all.

We'll definitely be back.
author: Erica G.

description:
Food: Pretty good
Service: Pretty good
Atmosphere: Very fancy
Crowd: Lots of gray hair
author: Joshua G.

description: Came here for the first time tonight with my husband and another couple. Really great, quiet neighborhood vibe. Loved the simple decor and the restaurant was very nice and clean. The menu  was small but had a great selection, I started with the Brussels sprout salad and had the pork chop as my entree. My husband had anchovies starter  and the duck leg . We loved our meals! Everything was cooked perfectly and had the right amount of seasoning. I usually share with my husband and after our delicious Meyer lemon pudding and coffee he asked, "how was the pork?" It was so good I didn't even give him a taste! Lol we will definitely return to this little gem.
author: Michelle H.

description: Came here with friends. All-around tasty food, especially the duck. I was also surprised to get 5 or so scallops in the appetizer dish.  My only complaint is that it was a bit on the pricey side (we paid $414 for 5 people and weren't sickeningly full). I'd definitely go back again!
author: Susan M.

description: Wonderful place for a birthday dinner! Everything we had was delicious!! Scallops with Jerusalem artichokes, salmon w capers and apples, shishito peppers, lentils w chanterelles .... and the persimmon pear crisp to finish
author: Rachel D.

description:
It took my entree an hour and ten minutes... does anything else even matter?

The food was very good. Just know that the kitchen is very slow and that you'd end up paying $65 per person without any drinks included.
author: Ido Jonathan E.

description:
A hidden gem!  The restaurant atmosphere is romantic yet casual.  Appreciate the option to sit at a table or the counter, always fun to mix it up from time to time.  Plus you could sit closer to your mate if you're into that. ;)

We ordered the calamari which was perfectly cooked and tasty.  Nothing out of the ordinary there which I appreciated, sometimes you just want a nicely grilled calamari.  The "smashed" peas crostini dish was very good, only con is that it had just a tad bit too much honey but I'd definitely order it again.  FYI - the peas weren't smashed like mushy peas, I would say they were gently smacked once!

Both the pappardelle and strawberry salad dishes were on point.  We opted for just these four items which felt enough for two people with a bottle of wine.   Overall very satisfied with every dish!  

They're not trying to push the envelope in terms of innovation, they offer simple and quality food in a beautiful space.
author: Joanne N.

description:
This place is cute. It's great for family dinner or girls dinner. But not for date dinner. It's too healthy and too cute. 
The food is delicious and light. It's absolutely my style: different vegetables dishes. We ordered blood orange and beets salad, that was full of flavor and light; sunchoke soup, that was delicious and very filling; calamari, that was my favorite dish; and the last dish we ordered was Brussels sprouts salad, that was so so for me - Brussels sprouts were raw and plain. 
Highly recommend to order soup and calamari. These are my favorite dishes. 
I definitely want to go back and try more dishes!
author: Jenna F.

description: I've been living in the neighbourhood since 2004 and had yet to come into this location even though it had been two different restaurants prior.  Gardenias is nothing less than amazing...excellent and attentive front of the house staff. beautiful interior, with fresh selections that go with a deep wine list. Try some of the vegetarian items peas, heirloom tomatoes if they're on the menu, and be sure not to miss the hand cut pappardelle.  So, so good!
author: Vince C.

description: Such a delicious dining experience! Can't wait to return. The service was terrific, and the neighborhood vibe was so welcoming.. I believe the menu varies, but everything we tried left us wanting to experience more.
author: Ann B.

description: I so wanted to love this restaurant after seeing it on Bay Area Check Please. We go to SF all the time and love trying new places. We had res at 8:30 and did not get seated until almost 9pm. There was no communication other than wait here at the bar which isn't really a bar. The only good service we received was from the person who was bringing us water. Our waiter seemed annoyed every time we asked for something. The main dishes were really good as we had the duck and the short rib and they were outstanding, but the service was so lacking it ruined the overall experience. We brought a bottle of wine as we were celebrating. The only time he poured our wine when he wanted to push us along to finish up. They charged us corkage and asked for them to waive it since the person at the bar opened it and we received little service going forward. Super cute place and romantic but with poor service, it's hard to to have a good overall experience. They also marked us as a no show on Open Table. Too many restaurants out there, that we won't come back.
author: Patrick G.

description:
Agh, I am disappointed to write this review.

I brought my BF here last night for his birthday dinner. From the start the service was slow -they had ran out of wine menus so we had to wait for them to print off more in the back. There seemed to be only 1 server working the entire floor - I actually felt for him.

We started with the calamari - it was meh. About 15 min after we finished the calamari, my stomach started doing flips and we both fell quiet, as we both didn't feel ok. For the main course my BF got the duck, and I got the short rib. It was comparable to a wedding dinner.

I only had about 5 bites of my entree so my BF kindly ate the rest of mine, although I knew he didn't feel well either.

His birthday ended abruptly as we asked for the check ASAP, and both headed home to be sick and lay on the couch miserable. 

Also, I understand the wine is on tap - but should it come out so foamy? $14 for a glass of foamy mediocre wine was also a low point to this place.
author: Angela B.

description: Super cute spot. Food was great and the wine list was interesting and diverse. However, our service was so awkward and disrespectful it almost (almost) made it not worth it. She was not only extremely curt but was also seemingly under the influence of something. Luckily the company that night was amazing so it didn't totally ruin the experience, but between her spilling wine everywhere, pouring water all over my appetizer and being unpleasantly rude, it was a little startling and kind of worrisome. Again, food and wine were awesome. Whoever manages the spot needs to do a performance review of their staff ASAP and get rid of the unprofessional folks.
author: Emily G.

description: Really cute spot and farm to table fresh ingredients. They were very accommodating of my vegan diet and my entree of mushrooms and tahini sauce was delicious and filling. Service was great as well.
author: Michelle L.

description: While the food was great, they knocked over a wine glass that broke and spilled all over me.  It was from our own bottle of wine and they didn't even offer a free replacement glass.  What a shame that the bad service ruined an otherwise great place.
author: Savannah D.

description: I'm not sure why this place isn't super popular but this is my go-to place for when I'm in a crunch for a reservation and craving delicious food or need to take someone out on a whim. The ambience is quaint and peaceful (you won't be hearing your neighbor's entire conversation). The service is great and almost every single thing on the menu is delectable. I highly recommend the ricotta crostini and the scallops.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Lovely intimate restaurant. We started with their cheese plate, my husband had the New York w/polenta and I had the Ricotta Ravioli with brown butter and broccolini  and for dessert we shared a meringue cloud with Meyer lemon ice cream with huckleberries. 
I wish I lived here, I'd come once a week.  Servers were knowledgeable and friendly! Try it.
author: Diana S.

description: This is a wonderful neighborhood spot for a romantic date night or dinner with friends. The ambiance and decor are lovely and perfect for a casually dressy evening out. The four of us ordered different apps and entrees, and we were all extremely happy with our meals. Service was kind and attentive. We'll definitely be back!
author: SfMom O.

description:
I didn't get it. Pretty plates but everything lacked serious flavor - and it looks like a lot of other reviewers agree with that. I'm not cheap when it comes to good food, but like hell that meal should have been the price it was for what it tasted like. 

Sad to report I wasn't impressed, and won't return.
author: Nicole M.

description: Good food and service. Maybe a bit pricy compared to some other similar places in Pac Heights / Nob Hill
author: Thibault L.

description: The ambiance was lovely. I thought the service was impeccable, so several stars for that. The wine list was overpriced for wine on tap, and none of the wines we had were particularly good. The scallop appetizer had good flavor, but we asked how many scallops were on it before we ordered and were told four. It came with only three and two of them were gritty, and on one of my bites I pulled a long blonde hair out of my mouth which was super gross. (Nobody at the table was blonde.) We told the server and she removed it from the bill, which was nice. The short ribs were okay, kind of a small portion once you removed the bones. The steelhead was delicious itself, and the sauce was nice, but the fingerlings on the side were totally hammered. Just chewy flavorless rocks basically. I would not go back to this restaurant. There were a couple of high points but way too many lows for the prices they charge.
author: Traci R.

description:
I like the updated vibe,  yet still neighborhood feel of this place, it's casual enough for a weekday dinner and nice enough for a date night.  The servers were friendly, but could be more attentive and professional.  

The food however, just didn't make an impression on me.

We started with the beet ravioli, which were interesting but lacked in flavor and arrived warm, like they were sitting there a bit long waiting for the server.  I think the filling could have used some flavor to cut the richness of the butter sauce.

Then the calamari, this was just an awful dish, and if the waiter bothered to stop by and ask, I would have given that feedback and sent it back.  The calamari were hard and rubbery, I didn't really understand if this was a salad or what it was supposed to be, but by far one of the worst calamari dishes ever.

The short ribs were next, they were nice, a bit fatty, I'd say the portion was a bit small, but overall a nice dish, however nothing creative about it.  The sides were polenta and carrots.

We also had dessert, not sure what it was, it looked like a soup of cream with some crumbles, too sweet, couldn't taste the cherries and presentation was not attractive.  I expected a layered pastry of sorts by the waiter's description.

We had a nice time, wine was great and the place wasn't overly loud, the table spacing was nice, at least in the front side, so we could actually talk.

I hope they improve, Fillmore area needs some new blood and more contemporary food.
author: Inga W.

description: Excellent atmosphere. Wonderful and sophisticated comfort food. Great, friendly service. And seriously incredible desserts.
author: Alec P.

description: So happy this opened in our hood. Fresh ingredients. Lovely service. Casual atmosphere. The short ribs are more like pot roast than short ribs, but still tender and tasty. Ravioli were delicious, but large black pepper pieces ruined a few bites. Arugula salad was good but kumquats were bitter. So some good and some not so good, but overall good enough to go back in particular because we can walk.
author: Nancy R.

description:
I wish I could give Gardenias a better review.  

We decided to try Gardenias for our anniversary dinner. Our reservation was at 7:30 p.m. We showed up five minutes late, but typically a restaurant will hold your reservation for 15 minutes before giving it away, so we weren't worried. The location of G is lovely, tucked away in a tree-covered neighborhood on Sutter. I had actually learned about G from just walking to and from work. 

The food, in my opinion, was spectacular. For starters, we ordered the peas and ricotta on crostini, the calamari, and the beet ravioli - they were all special dishes. The peas and ricotta on crostini was probably my favorite - the flavors worked well together and all of the ingredients were noticeably fresh. The calamari was also outstanding, grilled perfectly and served with a perfect amount of heat, it did not disappoint. The beet ravioli was also lovely, with fresh flavors and parmesan cheese, I could have probably eaten 8 more ravioli by myself (the serving size is 2 ravioli). I asked for bread and butter, which by the way, costs $3.50 (only in San Francisco do you pay for bread and butter). 

Before I continue raving about the food, I want to again note that we had a reservation for two people at 7:30 p.m. Our reservation was not honored, and it was not okay. When we walked in and told the host/server we had a reservation, he said that it would be 20 minutes. What? Why? We could have walked in off the street and waited 20 minutes. Because we were in good moods and didn't want to let this rather large oversight spoil the evening (or our anniversary), we took a seat at the bar (where, we were informed, we could also enjoy dinner), and ordered some beer (beer and wine only) and some starters. Over an hour later, at 8:40 p.m., we still had not been seated at a table. I flagged down our server and asked to speak with the manager, WHICH I NEVER DO. She came over, and when I expressed to her how disappointed I was that our reservation was not honored, she did not seem to care. In fact, she didn't even apologize for making us wait for over an hour for a table despite the fact that we had made the reservation far in advance. She just said it was busy and shrugged. We would have left, but we wondered where we could go with no reservation on a Saturday night in San Francisco. 

We were then seated at a table, finally. The server came up to us and asked if we wanted to order dessert. What? We hadn't even ordered entrees yet. We ordered dinner, which was also incredibly yummy. For him, the short ribs. For me, the pesto fettuccini and the seared scallops (both small plates because I'm indecisive). I loved both of my dishes, and my boyfriend's entrée was outrageously tasty. 

Our bill came and nothing on the bill was taken care of. I wasn't really looking for G to do that, but it would have been a nice gesture, considering the poor service we received. I don't think I'll be back to G's. It's a shame, because I love the food, but they have got to get their act together. Don't take reservations if you can't handle them. Sad face.
author: Sunny S.

description: I ate here a couple of years ago and remember it being very good.  I came back again and was disappointed.  The service was good.  We were seated next to a very loud table.  When another table opened we asked to be moved and we were.  However the food was not as good as I recalled.  I had the slow cooked duck leg, which was very good.  The other guests had the swordfish and pork chop, both were over cooked.  My friend likes his meat well done, but the pork chop was over cooked even for him  However, the flavors for both were good.  Appetizer was good, the gnocchi, very tasty.   Desserts were good.  I object to paying for bread, at these prices it should be included.  It is rather pricy.  It was $110 per person with wine.
author: David F.

description: Had a lovely birthday dinner here for my mom. Tried several dishes to share. Everything was excellent!
author: Dana R.

description:
I feel like some of the negative reviewers may have gone to the Burger King down the street by mistake, because this cute, local restaurant was great for me. I was impressed with the vegetarian dishes -- the Fugu Persimmon Bruschetta with Ricotta was a stand-out success, and the Roasted Beet Ravioli, was a pleasant surprise, not overly salty but still very flavorful. The service was quick and attentive.

Am I the only one who doesn't mind paying for bread? News flash: if you go to a restaurant and get the bread for "free," the restaurant is just raising the prices of the other dishes to pay for bread for everyone. This restaurant gives you the option to opt-out and not order bread, if you want. Love it!

The only dish that missed the mark for me was the Risotto with Wheat Berries, Squash and Garbanzos. The texture and temperature was delicious, but the flavor was a little flat. The Mushrooms Reggiano on top were perfectly cooked, and they _made_ the dish.
author: Dave N.

description:
Woodward Gardens was the excellent restaurant these people had before they opened Gardenias a few years back.  Had been twice and neither time really enthusiastic about the result but decided to try it again.  

The first negative was paying #5.00 for 4 small slices of bread, and just OK bread, nothing great, also paying $4.00 for a very small helping of olives.

The Gazpacho, the Roasted Chanterelles, and the persimmon salad were all excellent.  

The $32 steak was tough and flavorless.  The Long Cooked Duck was the same price and not worth it.

The service was OK but the worst part is that nobody seemed to care,   

It's very noisy.  We're not going back
author: Norman R.

description:
Love the ambience and the place but food was mediocre. Salmon was over decorated with onions, Brussels sprouts, couscous, berries, too many flavors competing with each other rather than complimenting. Crepes were horrible, over cooked and mushy. 
Server needs and attitude adjustment. Cocky and obnoxious. Perhaps the reason why such an adorable place only had 5 occupied tables on a Thursday evening. 
I can accept mediocre food for a great ambience and service but bad service is a deal breaker esp in an expensive restaurant. Too bad...hire professionally trained servers who know customer service.
author: Saf A.

description: This one is a hidden gem! We came across this restaurant just walking by the street and it turned out to be one of my favorite meals. We got a table in the outside garden area. I would highly recommend the outside seating if it's a good weather day. I got the socca cake entree and it was delicious! Also, the server was super nice with on point service. 5 stars!
author: Karan G.

description: Every dish is thoughtful and well-executed. The menu is a little limited, but we loved each dish we ordered. The parsnip mash with the short ribs far exceeded expectations!
author: Emily F.

description: I randomly found this restaurant while searching for gazpacho in SF. Literally every item we ordered was amazing. The calamari had amazing blackened lemon rind that added such great depth to the dish. The "socca" cakes (garbanzo flour) were light yet totally satisfying. The steelhead trout came with a fragrant mustard/brown butter sauce that I would drink if I had the option. All of the small dishes we had were fresh and unique. We will definitely be back.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Atmosphere: Great. Nice, cozy, and romantic. Just the right amount of dim warm lighting. The restaurant even had an outdoor back area.

Service: Subpar. We were seated late even though we had reservations, yet the restaurant wasn't full. My water glass was never empty UNTIL towards the end of the meal when our server ghosted and never checked on us again. At the end, when the chef came by and asked how the meal was, I informed her the braised pork was too sweet. She completely ignored my comment, cleaned our table of our dishes, and walked off as if she heard nothing. I even had to question my significant other as to whether I spoke too softly, but he assured me I spoke quite loudly. He even commented on how odd it was that the chef walked off without acknowledging my comment.

Food: First off, bread and butter AREN'T complimentary. First time I've been to a restaurant that charged for that. The amount of bread given isn't even a grandiose amount. However, the bread was quite flavorful and had a nice crunchy exterior complimented by a soft interior. Celery apple soup was delicious and refreshing. Wait time for my entree was longer than I would expect for what it was. I ordered the braised pork and it took about forty minutes. It was incredibly tender, but overly sweet to the point of forcing myself to try to finish the dish so as to not leave the restaurant hungry. It almost tasted like a meat dessert dish. I eventually gave up forcing myself to eat it out of fear I would gag and cough the food back up. Other than the food, the wine list was pretty extensive. The beer list was desolate and full of broken dreams (three average beers on tap).

Overall: Would not dine again.
author: Jasmine M.

description: I had the salmon and it was excellent. this i a classy place and nice and quiet - that made the dinner much more relaxing than many places in SF that are so loud and have staff that are running around frantically.
author: ari s.

description: Such a cute space! Came in at 9pm on a Friday and sat at the bar. The Ravioli was fantastic.
author: Kylie P.

description:
We came here looking for what previously occupied this space and boy were we pleasantly surprised. Gardenias was a fantastic dining experience, could not ask for a better date night dinner. Our server Tatiana was so courteous and nice. She was attentive but not once interrupted or rushed us. 
Rarely does a meal maintain a very high level from apps to dessert but Gardenias managed it! We started with the pea crostini and whatever they did with the ricotta/pea combo has me craving whole sheets of that stuff. We opted to go with three "beginnings" and one entree to try more things. My girlfriend will never order or even eat dishes involving beets...except last night. The Roasted Beet Ravioli was cooked perfectly and the visual of a beet red dumpling was delightful. 
We followed that with the corn soup (not too sweet, complex) and the calamari (not overcooked, fave purée was crazy good). For our entree, we went with the sautéed salmon and it completed the meal. I haven't had much rouille (topping the salmon); its consistently was between a whipped butter and mayonnaise. Very light but rich and flavorful. Rarely do we opt for dessert but we devoured the strawberry tart. Not too sweet and a perfect end.
author: Jamey B.

description: From the wonderful owners of Woodward's Garden came Gardenias and we could not be happier.  The food, wine, waitstaff and atmosphere were all impeccable.  I had the duck leg which was amazing and my friends had a few appetizers and the steak which were all delicious.  We also ordered two desserts and both were very nicely done.  We loved our server and the owner also stopped by and chatted with us.  In a city where customer service is lacking, it was refreshing to be at a place that made you feel at home.  We will definitely come back!
author: Shawna K.

description:
I so don't want to write this review because it'll let the secret out and next thing you know we won't be able to get in for dinner! But we love this place and want them to succeed.  

This is a gem of a restaurant with wonderful food, great ambience, lovely wines and beer selection at pretty "reasonable" prices.  I say "reasonable" because so many restaurants are so over priced in SF, but with Gardenia's it's not for what you get - just so you are clear, this is not a cheap eats joint, OK?

I love the small plated as well as the salads and many times that's enough for me.  My favorite small plate is the braised chicories - lovely crisp prosciutto and bittersweet chicories with enough balsamic to cut through the richness of the dish.  The seared scallops is also wonderful, a meal in itself for those with lighter appetites.  

Entrees we've had the braised short ribs several times (wonderful comfort food!) - tender, flavorful, and always satisfying! Last but not least, do save room for dessert.

Bread and butter is additional but truly worth it if you're a B&B fan!

So there...the secret's out but they deserve it!
author: Favoloso M.

description:
Pros: cute restaurant interior 
Cons: the food just isn't that great. We were disappointed. The wet ravioli was good but the short ribs and the calamari were just bland. There are so many good restaurants in the city with a cute interior and at that price point where I wouldn't go back.
author: Deal G.

description:
Came here with my parents to celebrate my birthday. The ambiance nice, though the walkways were a little too cramped due to a dense seating arrangement. The service was also good as well. 

Problem was the food was just okay. Certainly a hit on some dishes but a miss for others. 

First, we ordered bread and butter. Most restaurants I have visited provide bread and butter for free, but here there was a small fee. 4 bucks per roll if I remember correctly. Hey that's fine, I understand. But if you're going to charge for the bread, I would hope that it was hot out of the oven, fresh and soft. It was not.

For the appetizers, we got the artichokes, and the scallops. Scallops were pretty decent, though not enough actual scallops of course. The artichokes, not great. I'll be honest, I don't love artichokes, but we ordered it based on the waiters recommendation and out of the 4 of us at the table, only my mom liked it (this is probably a generous assessment). 

On to the main courses. I had the duck leg, which was great! I also sampled some of the short rib and the salmon, both tasted excellent as well. The fish was cooked perfectly. These were the highlights of the meal, and I can honestly say that everything was good as far as main courses. 

Dessert. Not great. We ordered 4 different types. The ice cream was packed with mint flavor-- excessively so in our opinion. The strawberry shortbread was probably the best, but nothing to write home about in any case.

To sum, great service, great ambiance, and good main dishes. The rest, was mediocre-- at best.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Having been to Woodward Gardens, I was thrilled my friend found Gardenias for us to try as part of our Diner's Club. All four of us had a lovely time at dinner -- the ambiance is casual, the service attentive, patient and warm. The food was excellent at times and other plates were less than stellar. That, however, did not detract from the overall joy of the meal with good friends: delightful comfort food, enjoyable service, neighborhood-y spot -- can't ask for much more in SF of 2016, which has changed almost beyond comprehension in the 26 years since I first moved here.

We had early reservations for a Friday night: 6pm. The restaurant was empty and we were given our choice of table -- a great start! When was the last time you got to pick your seating on a Friday night? We started with bright and creamy castelvetrano olives and each ordered our own glasses of wine. Our server, a sweet Spanish girl, knew the wine list and made good recommendations. We explained that we wanted to try many plates and to share everything -- she assured us that the portion sizes would be just right to do so. Perfect! 

The timing of the food was great -- she would bring 2-3 plates at once and allow us our unhurried taste of this, the passing of that plate, back and forth -- none of this forcing more plates onto an already full tabletop to ensure the table was turned over quickly. In the almost 3 hours we were there, we were never rushed, never ignored. Our server was friendly, knowledgable and warm throughout -- even though the restaurant became very full and very busy within an hour of our arrival. 

We started with the artichoke small plate -- it was fine, but not mind blowing. Maybe it would be better a little later in the season? The vegetables with bagna cauda were "meh" for me. The veggies were fresh and good -- tricolor carrots, baby fennel, celery, watermelon radish -- but the bagna cauda was not well blended and so just ended up being dipping oil for fresh veggies. Could have done without either of these small plates.

Now the ricotta raviolo was AH-MAZING! The pasta was made with some type of whole grain -- don't know what it was, maybe spelt? Delicious and hearty on the outside, creamy and melty on the inside. Definitely large enough for all 4 of us to share: each got a huge bite. YUM! We got a blood orange salad to share -- the flavors were there but the blood orange should have been segmented more finely, and the nuts chopped more delicately. This is nitpicky stuff, people! Order it anyway, it was a fine counterpoint to the richness of the raviolo. We ended the small plates with the seared scallops -- a hit! I had imagine 2 large scallops that we'd have to cut into small pieces but we got 5-6 scallops on a delicious bed of lentils. Perfection!

Finally, we ordered 2 entrees to split: The falling-off-the-bone duck leg and the savory-sweet-fennel-y short ribs. I could eat those short ribs for days! Both entrees were hearty, flavorful and really hit the spot for a chilly spring evening! 

We were satiated but still ordered dessert because it's our custom. Our server encouraged us to get the strawberry tart -- caramelized, brown butter, I don't know -- but it was such an amazing end to a wonderful meal! We also had an olive oil cake -- great but the strawberry tart had it beat.

If you've read this far into my too-long review, you're messing up & not making reservations to Gardenias right now. Do a date night, go with a small group of friends, take your parents....heck, go by yourself. But do yourself a favor and enjoy this friendly food -- your soul will be pleased.
author: Yasi S.

description: Really delightful dinner. Service was attentive and friendly without being obsequious. The food was uniformly very very good. We had a broad selection of things from the pea crostini to the fig and huckleberry tart. Every time we got a new dish our tables reaction after trying git was 'wow that is really good'. Simple - is a good way - first rate ingredients perfectly prepared.
author: Charles S.

description:
I was pretty sad when Cafe Kati closed, and the replacement was kind of disappointing.  So, when this place opened, it looked promising.  I'd never been to the Woodward's Garden, but opinions seemed pretty favorable.

So, this place fits in really well with the neighborhood.  Casual-ish, upscale, friendly staff, and some unique flavors that fit pretty well.  We had 3 dishes, and two of them had a blend of savory and sweet that blended perfectly.  The other had more traditional flavors, but quite refined.

It's a little too pricey for me to go too often, but still within reach where it doesn't necessarily need to be a special occasion.
author: masa s.

description: Kind of obsessed with this place right now. We came here in the autumn and although the food was good, it didn't make much of an impression on us at the time. However, we tried again a few days ago, and the food was awesome! The menu is creative and organic - if a group of fairies in a forest glen decided to open a fine dining restaurant, they would use this menu. Every dish we ordered - from the soup to the salad to the mains to the dessert - was a winner. The wine list is also spectacular. I can't wait to try what's next.
author: Convict T.

description:
A total gem and great addition to the neighborhood. We live across the street from Gardenias and are so lucky to have it close by. We've eaten here a few times and each time the food has been absolutely fantastic. No fancy or hip food frills - just really good, beautiful, delicious food and wine. The decor is also stunning and I always admire the floral arrangements.

We order the raviolo each time and it's amazing. I dream about this raviolo. All of the "small" and "beginnings" dishes are very good so my husband and I usually share 4-5 of these dishes to share for our entire meal.

Crossing my fingers and toes that this restaurant has a long lifespan in this location, as past restaurants haven't had much luck.
author: Simone B.

description: Food was excellent, service was attentive and, again, the food was excellent... beer list is small, but the selections are well-chosen.  Wine list is more expansive and interesting.  It has a great neighborhood vibe, perfect for date night. We will definitely be back!
author: Rob D.

description:
Very romantic. We visited for dinner last weekend and it was a perfect date night spot.
The three grain risotto was the bomb!
author: Will H.

description:
That is the problem with Yelp, everything is a four star. All 8 people in my party thought collectively this was the worst meal they have had in a restaurant in San Francisco in a long time. Let me start by saying that the wait staff is understaffed and undertrained( I had to ask our waiter to wipe down the table before setting down new silver wear. The food was so average and the portions were so small that after the meal we were all starving....and I am 5.4 and 130 pounds, so I don't need a lot of food to fill me, and I was starving. 
The short ribs were awful and there were only 2 per plate and once you pick away the fat and connective tissue, you are left with four bites of meat. The calamari was dry and rubbery and really the whole experience was awful. I unfortunately picked this place for our group and now have a huge black eye because the experience and most importantly the food was so below below par.
author: Noe V.

description:
I had never made it to Woodward's Garden, but it was my old man's go to spot.  He was sad when it closed, but so happy when he got wind of the new spot and concept.  So, we were dying to go.

I did some sleuthing about when it was finally LIVE.  They are only open right now Thurs-Mon for dinner, with a last seating at 8pm, so we took a Monday 8pm spot via Opentable.  The patio looks great, but they are still waiting on the permit for it so, stay tuned.

The space is sleek and clean, with tables and a lovely eat at counter.  Lots of walk in opportunities.  We had a table with our reservation, but opted for the counter as it is my old man's preference.  It wasn't too crowded, so we were able to chat with the staff and have some fun.  It feels like a place where that will be the norm, even when it is slammed.

Once seated, Margie came over and brought us menus.  The food is always going to change based on availability, but there are a few staples.  We started with the cucumber gazpacho and a seasonal veggie plate.  The gazpacho was mine, and lovely.  It was a punch of cucumber flavor, with some kick (jalapeno), and these great radish bits too cool off the heat.  The old man had the veggies, but kindly shared them - they were earthy and fresh, and such a warm (as in comforting) way to start our meals.  Dinner was: the wheat berry risotto for him and the braised short ribs for me.  I sadly forgot to try his, but he said it was creamy, filling and yet still light.  My ribs were beautiful cooked and seasoned, but the polenta they were on: I wanted to bathe in it.  It was a different texture than most, but it complemented the ribs perfectly, and the flavor off the charts.

We were more than full - the portions are what I would call perfect, not tiny waif-like, but not middle-american gluttonous.  But, early in the meal, I saw the olive oil cake go by, so that was happening.  My olive oil cake was really special.  All the lightness and texture that such cakes are marked by, and none of the over-powering nuttiness they can have in less skilled hands.  The old man got the chocolate raspberry tart, and it was so delicate.  The chocolate is an underneath lawyer, so I forgot it was there until I bit into it, and it balanced the raspberry tartness perfectly.  

The whole meal set us back about $86 (and I had wine), which in SF for 3 courses x 2 people plus wine for me, is really quite a treat.  The old man is already set for dessert date there this week, and dinner next.  So, that should tell you it is up to snuff.  

And, though I never went to Woodward's Garden, I could appreciate very easily and straight away why people love Margie so much, and why the place had so many loyal folks.  When we were there, she was all about the place, doing everything from clearing plates to giving advice.  She told us how much she loved the new spot, and how happy she is; I think that comes through pretty clearly with everything we enjoyed.  Welcome to the neighborhood Gardenias!
author: Shannon N.

description:
LOVE this place, one of my favorite meals in SF in the past year.  This is the kind of charming, wonderful neighborhood spot that I don't want anyone else to find out about, but I also want everyone else to find out about because it's the kind of restaurant that deserves all the business in the world.  

For starters, the service was impeccable in a helpful but not overly bothersome way. As for the food, everything was as delicious as I could have hoped for on a cozy night in this little neighborhood gem.  I had the pork should braised in milk which was one of the most delicious pork preparations I've ever enjoyed, and started with the crostini with brocolli rabe, garlic, and other magic.  The olives for the table, the bread, all fantastic.  Wine selection was perfect.

Rooster Tail didn't make it here before, and I think there is something a bit challenging about this location.  However, given Gardenias ambiance, food, and service, I look forward to coming back to this neighborhood gem ALL THE TIME.  Keep up the great work, Gardenias.
author: Jesse H.

description:
A charming neighborhood place serving a small menu of modern American upscale comfort food. You wouldn't find cutting edge food here nor must have dining but what it does, it does quite well.

The food was all good except the fish a local opah that was overcooked and dry. The rest of the food was good well and had lots of flavour. The gazpacho and the potato soup both had delicious flavour. The raviolo was probably the best dish we had-very simple with a ricotta filling and burnt butter.

The cheese plate was disapointing with only two slices each of two cheese that were a bit too cold. 

The service was excellent almost too friendly and the noise level was very good. This is a good bet if you are in the neighborhood and want a comforting delicious meal.

The restaurant and bathroom is wheelchair accessible.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: I am so glad this place is open!  After Woodwards closed I was very sad but Gardenias is a fresh new take.  The space is bright and inviting and the food is delicious.  Excellent service, fresh unique recipes.
author: K C.

description: Welcome to Babette's Feast. Margie runs a gem of a bistro in the Fillmore. Amazing crostini with peas and mint. Socca entree was delicious. Steelhead grilled with new potatoes and madeira sauce was delectable. Ricotta ravioli was as big as a quesadilla and delightful with cranberry beans! We enjoyed the homemade plum tart and chocolate merangue with sorbet! Tableware is a hoot! Real china and silver place settings..Can't wait to return!
author: Catharine N.

description: I have been to Gardenias twice now and they do not disappoint. This is a quiet and intimate place with an modern aesthetic- perfect for dates or small groups/ dinner with parents where ambient noise could be an issue.  The servers are attentive and informed about all dishes and wines on the menu.  All of the smaller plates are excellent for sharing and beautifully presented.  The standout main dish is the short rib with mashed parsnips- something you do not see on a lot of SF menus.
author: R G.

description:
Solid with moments of inspiration or at least recollection. The small plates have been most exciting in our few trips, including opening week. Mediterranean socca, crostini, gazpacho, and raviolo have been standouts, with some variations on the different trips.

Our most recent trip demonstrated much improved service and a friendliness to shared plates. The tap wine list is interesting enough, with some excellent French and Italian selections.
author: Sam P.

description:
Amazing!!!!!
At long last these two food Pioneers have a new home. Impeccable and sophisticated. Tap wine curated with thought. Can't wait to go back.
author: Stu G.

description: I was looking for a restaurant to go to with my family one evening and we went on Yelp in the afternoon and came across Gardenias. This was exactly what we were looking for! We immediately made a reservation and I can't wait to go back to try more of their seasonal dishes. The service was good and the food was even better. Highly recommend the Socca cake!
author: betsy r.

description: Great dining experience on all fronts. The service was prompt and the ambience incredibly cozy. The restaurant was decently occupied but didn't feel loud or chaotic. All the food was well portioned and prepared. We started with the orange beet salad, had the salmon for the entree and finished with the cherry tart and toffee custard. The salmon was outstanding (flavored and cooked to perfection), as was the toffee dessert. Definitely a gem in the area!
author: A A.

description: Thoroughly satisfying food -- interesting combinations of ingredients and flavors, but plating and portions place it squarely in the the comfort food camp. Small, low key place perfect for romantic dates and small gatherings with family and friends. I wish we had a place like this in our neighborhood! We went in winter and the menu reflected the season, so I suspect they change the menu regularly. Our service was impeccable, we had a reservation and they seated us right away. We werent super organized, but the server was very patient with us. We shared everything so they worked out how to course it appropriately. Each course was solid, from bites, to starters, to mains, to dessert. Will definitely be back.
author: Rob K.

description: A nice addition to the Fillmore neighborhood. Delicious food! Good service! Good vibe! Perfect for date nights! We ordered the Chicken liver Crostini with pickled Cherri's, Gazpacho, ravioli, mussels, game hen, the short ribs and for desserts we got the olive oil cake with figs. Everything that we ordered was cooked to perfection! Will definitely eat here again.
author: Soma M.

description: Lovely meal! I reccomend the braised short rib and mushroom risotto!m and dessert is excellent and the ambience is amazing!
author: Holly B.

description:
If you liked Woodward's Garden, you will love Gardenia's.  Everything I had there was top notch and some things were excellent.  I would particularly recommend the slow cooked pork shoulder -- it was as tender and tasty as I have ever had and was served with an delectable savory sauce.
The only downside to the restaurant is the deafening noise level.
author: Peter H.

description:
I have never felt compelled to write a restaurant review until now.  My best hope is that the owners take note...if they want this place to survive.  NB: I have worked in restaurants and I am always willing to give the benefit of the doubt and am so very rarely not willing to tip at least 20%.

Beginning with the positive: the space is adorable and the Nebbiolo on tap and the gazpacho were delicious.  

Now, on to the sad remainder of the review.  We sat at the chef's counter.  Point #1: if you expose your kitchen to your customers you **MUST** have your sh*t together.  Otherwise it is like dining at your friends' house, as they teeter on the brink of divorce.

Our first server was a sweet french(?) girl who unknowingly traded off duties with another server who looked less than thrilled to be there.  They were the only two designated servers, but there was someone who appeared to be ab expediter who was also on the floor.  Two line cooks were behind the bar and communication among all parties was a hot mess.  Our gazpacho came in a timely fashion, and like I said, it was delicious.

Our two small plates, crudite and little gems salad seemed to be taking an awfully long time so server #1 checked in, saying they were on their way.  After another 15 minutes and checking with server #2, the little gems that we saw sitting on the counter for 20 minutes arrived to us, along with the vegetables.  Meanwhile, we could SEE that our entrees had been fired and were ready to be served at that time, so off to the heating rack they went, to dry out for 10 minutes.  

In a hurried frenzy the small plates were cleared and our mains were there, hot hot plates and all.  I had the pork shoulder which had dried out a bit after sitting around.  My husband had the guinea hen, which we both thought would be an actual guinea hen.  Maybe it was 1/3 of a guinea hen, which is like, 2 bites.  And it was accompanied by 1.5 halves of potatoes.  Not worth $27.

I get it.  Accidents happen.  But the couple next to us seemed to have a similar issue.  The owners are restaurant veterans, so I have a hard time seeing how they can let their establishment run like this on a Saturday night.  And like I said, if your kitchen is visible to your customers, don't mess up, and if you do, re-fire those mains and fix your mistakes.  And don't let your customers see the eye-rolling, the huffing and puffing, the stress, and the discord.  It's just not pleasant.  AND if you mess up, comp SOMETHING.  ANYTHING.  Acknowledge that you're having a bad night, and make it right!
author: alexis r.

description: Excellent new addition to the Fillmore / lower pacific heights neighborhood. Each item on the menu seemed compelling and had interesting ingredients that seemed to all pair very well. The service was great, the salad (kale?) was good and the pork shoulder on farro was outstanding (so tender!).
author: Sumit C.

description:
Absolutely lovely space, comfortable but refined - really enjoyed the atmosphere.  
Fresh, well-prepared comfort food in a gorgeous atmosphere.   The current menu could use a few tweaks, as could the service which was extremely friendly if a bit harried.  
Two of us had five items of varying sizes and while everything was delicious, it was a bit one note.  Again, I'll stress that we enjoyed all of it (though didn't finish any of the larger items).  I just wish there was a bit of variation in flavors and some lighter options.  The current menu (not the one on the website) is on the heavier side with a very fall/winter feel to it.  I greatly appreciate seasonality, but a little acid somewhere in our meal would have gone a long way.  
I am currently eating my leftover squash crepes for breakfast and I feel exactly the same as when I had them for dinner - delicious but just a little too heavy and sweet.  And there is something in the flavoring that is very similar to the celery/parsley soup and the short ribs. 
I'd like some heavier wines to cut through the current menu - they were much too light for the current food offerings, though tasty and reasonably priced.
I will definitely go back to Gardenias though I might wait for Spring....
author: Ellen H.

description: The food's pretty great: I had the kabocha soup, the scallops, and the game hen (perhaps a bit under seasoned, but still very good with the potatoes and greens). We all shared some bottles of chardonnay. Our entrees took quite a bit of time to show up, but I'll assume it's because they were busy (full restaurant on a weeknight). Great Fillmore pregame spot.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Been here a few times and always leave thinking it was our best meal since the previous time. The restaurant has a great ambiance and is always clean. Margie and her staff are always welcoming. The gnocchi and ravioli are must have appetizers. I've had the duck, short ribs, risotto, and the fish one time each and all four were awesome. The short ribs would be my favorite because you get the most of it. The Carignan and Grenache are priced right and are the two go-to's.
author: J.A. S.

description:
This was a huge disappointment. We waited so long for this restaurant to open in our neighborhood! We had been at the other restaurant they owned in the Mission (Woodward) and loved the experience. I cannot say the same of this new place. 

Food was average and overpriced for what you get. Service was sloooow. Waiter was rude and crude. They threw the $14 cheese plate on the table w/o even introducing the cheeses. Well I guess because there was not much to introduce on the plate. Two small piece of ordinary cheese on a plate!

I had the corn hen. Actually 1/2 for $24. I could have eaten it in two bites. It was dry too!

Our table neighbors ended up leaving before they even started. They said they felt they were pressed and waiter (the blonde lady who seems to be one of the two owners) was too rude.


Well ...too bad. We hoped this would become our around the corner favorite restaurant. 
I really hope the two owners get in the spirit of this neighborhood and start being nice and connecting with the people!
author: Antonella O.

description:
I recently had dinner with two friends at the quite new Norwegian-inspired restaurant, Gardenias, in the lower Fillmore area.  The room was spacious with clean lines, and much less noisy than most S.F. restaurants.

My dinner started with grilled asparagus with prosciutto and a bit of chopped hard-boiled egg.  The asparagus was still warm, but crisp and delicious, as was the entire dish.  For my main course I had grilled salmon on a bed of roasted potatoes, leeks, and spinach.  Once again, the fish was perfectly grilled, the ingredients worked well together, and the amount was generous.  For dessert I had their mission fig tart with whipped cream and a blackberry sauce -- to die for.  One of my companions had pork for her main course, the other had their risotto; and both loved their dinners.

To top it all off, the service was attentively provided by a young Spanish woman; and the prices, we thought, were quite reasonable by S.F. standards.  All three of us promised our friendly server that we'd by back to Gardenias soon.
author: Gerald W.

description: Hidden gem. Walked in with my family without reservation and Joshua placed us at the bar and he along with a younger girl (forgot name, sorry!) took great care of us. The food was excellent, kudos to the chef. The calamari was the best I've ever had. Will come again.
author: Joe O.

description:
The food was a bit disappointing. 
2 small slices of cheese for a $14 cheese plate and 2 crackers it's excessive. 
The hen was dry. The polenta was too rich and the ribs bland. 

Unfortunately, the service was very slow and disorganized. We waited at least 15 min between the starters and the main course. I asked for a glass of water with my main course. I was almost done when the water was served. 

The establishment is new and the machine is not perfectly oiled. However, it is too pricey for the quality of the experience.
author: Giovanni T.

description: Really enjoyed this restaurant. The interior is very well done and inviting.  The beet ravioli was a great starter, and salmon entree was great as well. I will come back.
author: Shawn C.

description: Visiting from southern California, we dropped in to this small restaurant at about 6 PM and were greeted immediately by a warm server who sat us immediately. The menu is fantastic, with many vegetarian options. (There are items like short ribs as well.) I don't know anything about the chef, but from appetizer to dessert there were new combinations of flavors which made this a meal to remember. Great wine list, and the service was spot-on. Prices are on the higher side but we splurged, and I think it would be possible to enjoy this restaurant without spending too much. It was quiet--the perfect place for conversation. (You don't find that every day!)
author: Brad R.

description: My experience here was not at all what I expected for a $$$ restaurant. Personally, I am not a picky person and typically have an open mind for when bad things happen but it was hard to leave here being satisfied. First of all, we had a reservation that has been called in advance by a few days at 8pm. I arrived exactly at that time and was the first in my party to arrive so by then they just started setting our table. However, by 8:35 my whole party has been there now and still was not seated. The waiters did come up to us to apologize for our wait and explained that the prior party at our table is taking a longer time than thought but what I didn't understand was that all around us there were tables empty that could've easily been filled by my party. Anyways, we were settled in our seats by 8:45 and I was hungry. Not going to lie, after all that waiting, I was hoping my party would get a little more attention from the workers the rest of our visit. However, it took us some flagging down of the waiter to even order our meal and that just added on more time for the wait. By now my thoughts on the service was going down but I was still excited to see how the food would be. We ordered the beet ravioli to share which I will say is very good and for my entree I ordered the $18 risotto. After really testing my patience, I once again felt like I had to test it more since the entrees took some time to come out as well. Once my risotto did come out, I was definitely not pleased. I know I'm not a master chef or anything but I know better that risotto is not supposed to be soaked in the water it's cooked in and should be of a more sticky consistency. Each scoop on my spoon was filled with soup or broth, and then some mushy rice. Flavor was good but I am very sure this isn't how an $18 dish should be. By the end of the night, I was left dissatisfied by the service and my entree :(
author: Erika Joy O.

description: Decent food, but got ignored a lot despite a mostly empty restaurant. Got seated late for our reservation. Waited a long time for our entrees - was just about to ask them if our order was forgotten when our food arrived. When asked how our meal was, got completely ignored as we responded. Service not worth the price. Oh, and the bread isn't free.
author: Michi K.

description:
I love this restaurant - the food and atmosphere were lovely! 

I went with a group of friends - we shared the starters and I especially liked the little gem salad and the chicken liver crostini. I had a delicious salmon as my main course and tried the hen, which was also tasty. Save room for dessert as the blueberry tart was the best I have had in years. All the desserts were impressive!

I will be coming back soon-
author: A W.

description: This is a neighborhood gem. I love how it's tucked away off Fillmore Street next to a cute little parklet.
author: Kristin B.

description: This is really a 3.5 but rounding up because there's definitely potential here. Stopped by on a whim this weekend and was pleasantly surprised. The atmosphere was cozy, the service was attentive, and the courses were well-timed. Environment = 4 stars. The food was good, but there were some hits & misses. The braised leeks were delicious and I'd also recommend the duck leg for a hearty main course. The calamari dish has got to go though. It was very disjointed -- a plate of sauteed calamari thrown on a bed of shredded lettuce, with a couple shishito peppers on the side and a huge portion of aioli on top. It was messy and the flavors didn't work together. The brussels sprout salad was a rec from the waitress but was both lacking a bit in flavor and overly salty at the same time. Food = 3. I can tell the restaurant is focused on unique dishes and I applaud that creativity. The menu still needs some refining, but I will be back to try more!
author: Samantha K.

description: Wow this place is a hidden gem, we live in the area and was walking around looking for a place to eat  the food the service is ten out of ten, Joshua treated us like VIPs, we will be back for sure
author: Paul O.

description: This was the best date night meal we've had in a long time. Our waitress was a sweet young woman who not only offered me a taste of multiple wines when i had trouble deciding (on a glass, mind you, not a bottle), she emphasized that there was no pressure to order any of them. I settled on a lovely Barbera. We had the gnocchi starter- housemade, airy, slightly crisp on the outside, with fresh sweet snap peas, a hearty and flavorful white bean soup, and then we shared the short ribs with polenta. Everything was cooked to perfection, presented beautifully, and well-proportioned. The ambiance is romantic and cozy. This place is the antidote to overcrowded, over-hyped, overpriced downtown restaurants. It made me remember why I fell in love with eating out in San Francisco, well before all you Millennial Yelpers got out of high school.
author: SF Soccer Mom S.

description: Up until the last 2 minutes of dinner I would have rated Gardenias 5 stars.  My boyfriend and I went to Gardenia's for dinner on a Wednesday night at 6:45.  The food was amazing, the service was very good and we had just been saying how we couldn't wait to come back.  We had signed our check around 8PM when a different waiter came up to ask us to finish our time up at the counter.  I had less than half a glass of wine left, there were open tables, almost all of the counter stools were available and there was no one at the front waiting.  Not sure why after a $160 meal that lasted less than an hour and a half on a Wednesday I'd be asked to give up my seat for presumably no one especially when there had been tables there before us that were still lingering after we were asked to move.  If our reserved table was needed at a later time for a separate reservation that should have been something mentioned when we first got there.
author: Taylor R.

description: Delicious and interesting kind of nouveau French food. Lovely ambience and a little patio out back for warm days. We had the trumpet mushrooms, scallops, asparagus to start - all delicious. I had the mushroom risotto for my main - great vegetarian dish. A little unusual for a risotto - had barley and chickpeas - but was a great modified risotto dish. Nice wine selection and great service. I'm shocked this place isn't more packed.
author: Lauren S.

description: Delicious spot hidden away in Lower Pac Heights.  My husband and I were both pleasantly surprised to stumble upon this gem.  Everything we ordered was tasty, fresh and comforting.  The food is simply delicious and they aren't trying too hard.  We thoroughly enjoyed the Raviolo and Asparagus appetizers, Short Rib and Lamb Tagine entrees, and Strawberry Tart and Olive Oil Cake desserts.  I would order all of it again, especially the Short Rib and Strawberry Tart!  I saw one review that said the food was underseasoned -- I prefer less salt in my diet so I thought it was perfect but I could see why some might have a difference of opinion.  It was by no means bland -- quite the opposite -- and I savored each bite.  We will definitely be back again and again!!
author: J O.

description: Gardenias is the real deal, clearly the best restaurant in the neighborhood north of Geary. We stopped by without reservations on a saturday night after a film. We were seated at the counter which was very comfortable and allowed us to watch the kitchen. Everything we ordered was fantastic. The raviolo with roasted persimmon and the greens wrapped in prosciutto were both outstanding. I had the short ribs and my partner had the game hen. He kept making happy sounds with each bite. My short ribs were the best rendition I have had of that dish in years. The wine list is very interesting and offered us the opportunity to have wines we had never heard of. We picked a red from Northern Italy near the boarder with Germany. It was great. The orange cake was a little sweet for my taste so I was glad to be splitting it. The service was great, attentive but not intrusive. The dishes were well timed. All in all, I can't wait to go back. What a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Lee D.

description: I was a huge Woodwards fan and this couple's new venture Gardenias does not disappoint. Classic decor, a brief but excellent wine list and amazing service are just the icing on the cake. The main event---the cuisine---is just fabulous. The food is Inventive yet classic and made with seasonal and divine ingredients;Gardenias does not disappoint! Great place for an intimate and delicious meal.
author: Katherine B.

description: Healthy, stellar menu choices. Every dish was beautiful and tasted sensational. Very attentive service on both visits so far.
author: E L.
